title: Relative abundance of subsurface hydroxyl and molecular water species in silicate and aluminosilicate glasses
abstract: The interaction of water with glass has a profound impact on its mechanical, chemical, and kinetic properties. Water can enter the glass network either as molecular form (H2O) or hydroxyl species (OH). The resulting impact of water on glass properties depends on the relative concentrations of hydroxyl to molecular species. While attenuated total reflection infrared (ATR-IR) spectroscopy can be used to determine the presence of these species in the subsurface region of glass, there is currently no approach to characterize their relative abundance in the glass surface. In this paper, we propose a calculating method for quantifying the ratio of hydroxyl to molecular water in silicate glasses based on a combination of ATR-IR spectroscopy and secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS). The technique is applied to leached soda lime silicate and sodium aluminosilicate glasses under a variety of process conditions. The method presented in this paper offers a new avenue for understanding the multiple roles of water in silicate glass network structure and topology.

                  Introduction
                  Hydrous species in silicate glass surfaces can have significant impact on chemical durability, mechanical strengths, and mechanochemical properties of glass [1–8]. In soda lime silicate (SLS; also called soda lime silica or sodium calcium silicate) glass, hydrous species exist in two forms: hydroxyl group (SiOH) and molecular water (H2O). These subsurface hydrous species are introduced through surface treatments such as dealkalization with SO2 or difluoroethane, mechanical polishing, or aqueous leaching during the manufacturing; even in the absence of intentional surface treatment, atmospheric corrosion or weathering during handling, storage or usage in ambient air can drive dealkalization [9–12]. SiOH can be formed through reactions of protons or water with dangling network bonds such as non-bridging oxygen (NBO) at and in the glass surface. Water reactions with bridging oxygen (BO) can also form SiOH groups, but the high activation energy for this can limit the kinetics [13,14]. The reverse reaction is also possible. Overall, these reactions can be expressed as (although over-simplified):

                  At the same time, H2O molecules can ingress into the glass matrix [15–17]. Water transport can be enhanced when leached or corroded surfaces have a relatively “open” silicate network. Thus, the SiOH/H2O ratio is closely related to not only the glass composition, but also the silicate network structure [18,19].
                  Infrared (IR) spectroscopy is widely used to analyze the hydrous species in various types of glass. Titration and transmission IR have been utilized to determine the absorption coefficient of the OH stretching mode and the H2O bending mode of hydrous species in the glass bulk [20,21]. In the near-IR region (4000–6000 cm−1), combination bands are detected: O-H stretch (ν

                     ) around 4700–5300 cm−1 for H2O. Since their bands are not overlapped, it is possible to detect them separately [22,23]. Although near-IR is widely used for bulk analyses [24], it is often difficult to selectively detect the hydrous species present within a hundred nanometers or so from the glass surface. This is because the combination bands have very weak absorptivity [25]. In addition, the absorptivity of the SiOH combination band is reported to vary with the water content in the glass [21,26].
                  In mid-IR region (1500–4000 cm−1), the absorptivities of SiOH and H2O are quite large, making it easier to detect them with a surface-sensitive technique such as attenuated total reflectance (ATR) spectroscopy [27]. However, the ν
                     
                        OH
                      band is convoluted by the contributions from both SiOH groups and H2O molecules with varying degrees of hydrogen bonding interactions [27,28], and their absorptivity values vary with the strength of hydrogen bonding interactions [29,30]. Another complexity in ATR-IR analysis comes from the concentration gradient of hydrous species in the surfaces [31,32] and the decay of the evanescent wave intensity from the ATR crystal-glass interface to the bulk [33]. Due to these complexities, the ATR-IR analysis has been used only as a qualitative tool for the detection of hydrous species in the subsurface region, but not for the determination of the relative abundance or ratio of SiOH and H2O species.
                  This paper describes a mathematical algorithm to determine the relative abundance of hydroxyl and molecular water species (OH/H2O) in monolithic and flat glass surfaces based on the ATR-IR analysis and the hydrogen depth profile obtained with dynamics secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS). The ratio of OH/H2O concentrations was determined for two different sets of leached SLS glass surfaces: (1) polished SLS glasses with varying leaching times and (2) SLS glasses with different fictive temperatures under the same leaching conditions. The developed method was applied to hydrous speciation in the leached layer formed in sodium calcium aluminosilicate (NCAS) and sodium aluminosilicate (NAS) glass with similar sodium concentrations. In the case of aluminosilicate glass, the AlOH group can also contribute to the hydroxyl group. The calculation results provide deeper insights into the effects of the surface treatment time, thermal history, and bulk composition on the degree of subsurface hydration. With this algorithm, the ATR-IR analysis coupled with the SIMS depth profiling could be used as a method for determining the relative abundance of OH/H2O. If ATR-IR is combined with the hydrogen depth profile from the resonant nuclear reaction (RNR) method, one can obtain the absolute concentration of those two species [34]. But, the RNR technique is not readily available. The quantitative information on relative abundance of OH and H2O species in the glass surface would help understand the roles of these species in affecting surface properties. It could also enable estimating the surface glass transition temperature using recently developed topological constraint theory [35].

sections.Results and discussion:
3
                  Results and discussion
                  The leaching process of SLS in aqueous solution is an ion exchange process which is often accompanied by the ingress of molecular water [4,12]. When Na+ attached NBO (SiO−) is leached out and replaced with H+, then SiOH is formed. If one H2O molecule is associated with the newly formed SiOH group, then it is stoichiometrically equivalent to the hydronium ion (H3O+). The degree of hydration in the Na+-depleted layer has been studied by titrating the number of hydrogen atoms entered into the glass per Na+ ion leached out of the glass using the RNR between 1H and 15N [31,43,44]. These previous studies reported that the stoichiometric ratio between Na and H could vary from one (which means ion exchange with negligible ingress molecular water) to three (which would mean conversion of NBO to Si-OH and uptake of additional H2O). Depending on the glass network structure and the surface treatment/preparation history, this value could be any number between one and three. If the leached surface becomes porous, then it could even be higher than three. Since the relative intensities of ν
                        OH
                      and δ
                     
                        HOH
                      bands in ATR-IR will vary depending on the degree of hydration, the mathematical algorithm described in Section 2.1 could be used to quantify the relative abundance (m) of these two hydrous species (OH and H2O) in the glass surface. This principle was demonstrated in three cases – (i) polished SLS glass subjected to varying durations of leaching time (5–320 h) in pH 1 solution at 90 °C [12], (ii) SLS glass with different fictive temperatures leached in pH 1 solution at 90 °C for 600 h [41], and (iii) SLS, NCAS, and NAS glasses with a similar thickness of acid-leached surface layers [42].

                     3.3
                     Effect of bulk composition on relative abundance of OH/H2O in acid-leached layers
                     The SLS examples in the previous sections are the case where network modifiers (especially, Na+ ions) are leached without (or with minimally) altering of the glass network connectivity. Both the loss of network modifiers and the loss of network formers will affect the hydrous speciation. For example, the aluminum is an important network-forming element. In aluminosilicate glass, it exists as AlO4
                        − in the network and is charge-balanced with cations. When the pH of aqueous solution in contact with the glass is lower than 4, the aluminum species can be dissolved as Al(OH)4 in addition to the leaching of cations, while silica species remain in the leached layer (also called alteration layer) [54]. The effect of bulk composition on the hydrous speciation was studied by comparing the OH/H2O ratio (m) of the alteration layers with similar OH intensity after leaching in pH 1 at 90 °C for 320 h for SLS, 500 h for NCAS and 100 h for NAS [42].

Thus, the higher Al2O3 content in the bulk composition, the higher OH/H2O ratio in the alteration layer is expected. The loss of a larger quantity of the network former component leads to a larger decrease in the surface modulus and hardness [42].

When the relative abundance of hydrous species (OH/H2O) is to be compared with physical properties of the sample, the ATR-IR analysis should be carried out in the same condition as the physical property measurement for the sample prepared in the same way. This complication is unavoidable due to the non-equilibrium nature of glass.
                  
                  
                     3.5
                     Importance of estimating subsurface OH/H2O ratio
                     The relative abundance of hydroxyl species to molecular water has a significant impact on the topology of the glass network. The reaction of water with the glass to form hydroxyl species typically converts a bridging oxygen to two non-bridging oxygens, directly reducing the connectivity of the glass network. On the other hand, the incorporation of molecular water into the glass does not directly break bonds. A new topological constraint model introduced by Potter et al. [35] considers that molecular water strains the Si-O-Si bond angle, i.e., the weakest constraint in the glass network. This adds a strain energy to the network, reducing the amount of thermal energy required to break the constraint. The model of Potter et al. has been shown to provide an accurate prediction for the scaling of glass transition temperature with hydrous species in silica glass. With the newly developed experimental technique described in the current paper, the relative abundance of hydroxyl to molecular species can be directly measured and incorporated into the topological constraint model. In this manner, the impact of hydrous species on the modified surface region of glass can directly be linked to macroscopic properties calculated through constraint theory, including glass transition temperature, hardness, and chemical durability [58-64].
sections.Conclusion:
4
                  Conclusion
                  A simple mathematical algorithm was developed and demonstrated to calculate the relative abundance of hydroxyl species and molecular water (OH/H2O) in the leached or alteration layers of silicate and aluminosilicate glass. This method relies on the peak areas of the OH stretching and H2O bending modes of ATR-IR spectra and the total hydrogen depth profile from SIMS. The accuracy can be improved by validating or modifying assumptions used in the calculation. This method may provide the structural information critically needed for better understanding of surface mechanical properties and chemical durability.
